question.title: Will Joe Biden remain President through the end of July 2024 and not die before Saturday, July 26th, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (Eastern Time). This means he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment, making his VP the Acting President, does not cause a NO resolution as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution. (b) There is no official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. If both conditions are satisfied, the question resolves YES. If either or both conditions are not satisfied, the question resolves NO.

Event (a) is likely to occur because Joe Biden has not shown any signs of resignation or incapacitation that would lead to his removal from office. He is also in good health for his age, which reduces the likelihood of sudden death or incapacitation. However, it's impossible to rule out unforeseen circumstances entirely, such as a severe illness or accident. Event (b) is also likely to occur because there is no reason to believe that Joe Biden's death would be announced before market close on July 26th, 2024. Official announcements of high-profile deaths, especially those of sitting presidents, are typically made after verification and confirmation, which may take some time. Considering these factors, I would estimate the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 and not dying before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, to be very high, but not 100%. question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?

It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: There are several factors that suggest a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is likely to be signed by at least 20 House/Senate Democrats. Firstly, the fact that dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort to seal President Biden's nomination sooner than originally planned indicates a significant level of opposition within the party. The drafted letter circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) also suggests that there is a clear and organized effort to express dissent. Additionally, the fact that scores of Democratic members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy, as mentioned in the Politico context, further supports the likelihood of a public letter being signed by at least 20 House/Senate Democrats. Furthermore, the fact that multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmakers' signatures would also be sufficient to resolve the market to YES suggests that the threshold for resolution is relatively low, making it more likely that the market will resolve to YES.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20, and (2) fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?

(2) Will fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by fewer than 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of fewer than 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Joe Biden will remain President through the end of July 2024, I will consider various factors that could influence his presidency. Firstly, Biden is 82 years old as of 2023, which is relatively old for a President. While there is no indication of his health being a significant concern, his age could increase the likelihood of health-related issues. Additionally, there have been instances of previous Presidents experiencing health issues, such as Dwight Eisenhower's heart attack in 1955 and Woodrow Wilson's stroke in 1919. However, medical advancements and better healthcare systems have improved the chances of recovery and prolonged life expectancy. Another factor to consider is the possibility of resignation. While there is no indication that Biden plans to resign, previous Presidents have resigned due to personal or political reasons. For instance, Richard Nixon resigned in 1974 due to the Watergate scandal. Lastly, the 25th Amendment to the US Constitution allows for the temporary transfer of power to the Vice President in case the President is unable to discharge their duties. This does not necessarily mean that Biden will cease to be President, but rather that he will be temporarily unable to perform his duties. Taking these factors into account, I estimate that the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is relatively high, but not certain.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed from a primary ballot for federal office under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Biden cease to be President before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the condition is not met.

2. Joe Biden ceases to be US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) by resigning, dying, or otherwise leaving office. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not meet this condition, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

The question resolves as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the question resolving as 'Yes', we need to assess the likelihood of both conditions being met. The first condition requires Donald Trump to be officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. This is a complex process that involves state governments, courts, and legal documentation. While it's possible that some states might take action against Trump, it's uncertain whether this would happen on a large scale or before the specified deadline. The second condition requires Joe Biden to cease being the US President before the end of July 2024. This could happen through resignation, death, or other means. However, as of my knowledge cutoff, there's no indication that Biden plans to resign or is in poor health. The 25th Amendment is also not applicable in this scenario, as it would only lead to a temporary transfer of power, not a permanent cessation of Biden's presidency. Considering these factors, I would estimate the probability of the first condition being met as relatively low, around 0.2 (20%). This is because removing a major party candidate from the ballot is a significant decision that would likely face legal challenges and political backlash. The probability of the second condition being met is also low, around 0.05 (5%). This is because there's no clear indication that Biden plans to resign or is in poor health, and the 25th Amendment is not applicable in this scenario. To estimate the probability of both conditions being met, we need to multiply the probabilities of each condition. This gives us a probability of 0.2 * 0.05 = 0.01 (1%).

question.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is about predicting the outcome of a specific event at the 2024 Olympics. Given that the Olympics involve thousands of athletes from hundreds of countries, it is difficult to predict with certainty which countries will win their first-ever gold medal. However, we can use the law of large numbers to our advantage. As the number of participating countries increases, the likelihood of at least 5 countries winning their first-ever gold medal also increases. While we cannot know for certain how many countries will achieve this feat, we can use the probability of individual countries winning their first-ever gold medal and the large number of participating countries to make an educated estimate. According to the Olympic Games' historical data, around 50-60 countries have never won an Olympic gold medal. Assuming a roughly even distribution of chances for each country to win its first-ever gold medal, we can estimate the probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal. Using the cumulative distribution function of the binomial distribution, we can estimate the probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal as follows: Let p be the probability of a country winning its first-ever gold medal, which we can assume to be around 0.05-0.1 (a rough estimate based on historical data). The probability of exactly k countries winning their first-ever gold medal can be calculated using the binomial distribution formula: P(k) = (n choose k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k) where n is the total number of countries that have never won an Olympic gold medal, and (n choose k) is the binomial coefficient. We can sum up the probabilities of k=5, k=6,..., k=50 (the maximum possible number of countries that can win their first-ever gold medal) to get an estimate of the probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal. Using a rough estimate of p=0.075, we get: P(at least 5) ≈ 0.53. Therefore, our estimated probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal at the 2024 Olympics is approximately 53%.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, I need to consider various factors that could influence the outcome. The European Parliament elections are typically held every five years, and the 2024 elections will be the ninth parliamentary term. The European Parliament has 705 members, with seats allocated to each country based on its population. GUE/NGL (Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left) is a left-wing political group in the European Parliament, composed of socialist, communist, and green parties. While GUE/NGL has a significant presence in the European Parliament, it has traditionally been one of the smaller groups. To hold the most seats, GUE/NGL would need to gain a significant number of seats from other groups or perform exceptionally well in the elections. There are several factors that could impact GUE/NGL's performance in the 2024 elections: 1. Electoral trends: The European Parliament elections are often influenced by broader electoral trends, such as the rise of populist and nationalist parties, which could potentially benefit or harm GUE/NGL. 2. National election results: The performance of GUE/NGL's member parties in national elections leading up to the European Parliament elections could indicate their strength and potential for success in the European elections. 3. Campaigning and mobilization: GUE/NGL's ability to mobilize its supporters and campaign effectively could impact its chances of gaining seats. 4. Competition from other groups: Other political groups, such as the European People's Party (EPP), the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), and the European Conservatives and Reformists (ECR), may also compete for seats, potentially affecting GUE/NGL's chances. Given these factors, it's challenging to estimate the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections. However, I can provide a rough estimate based on historical trends and the current political landscape. In the 2019 European Parliament elections, GUE/NGL won 41 seats, which was a decrease from the 2014 elections. While GUE/NGL has a strong presence in some countries, such as Greece and Spain, it faces challenges in other countries where nationalist and populist parties have gained ground. Considering these factors, I estimate the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections as relatively low.

question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

question.title: Will the Month-over-Month US Core CPI increase by more than 0.1% in July?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the seasonally adjusted Core CPI for July 2024 increases by more than 0.1% compared to June 2024.

The Data for resolution will be https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPILFESL and will use the exact (not rounded) value.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability that the Month-over-Month US Core CPI will increase by more than 0.1% in July, I will consider various factors that could influence the Core CPI. Firstly, the Core CPI is a measure of inflation that excludes food and energy prices, which are volatile. This makes it a more stable indicator of underlying inflation trends. However, it also means that the Core CPI is less responsive to changes in global commodity prices. Secondly, the US economy has been experiencing a moderate expansion, with low unemployment and steady economic growth. This could lead to upward pressure on wages and prices, contributing to higher inflation. Thirdly, the Federal Reserve has been raising interest rates to combat inflation, which could slow down the economy and reduce inflationary pressures. However, the impact of interest rate hikes on inflation can take time to materialize. Lastly, historical data from the same period in previous years may provide some insight into the likely direction of the Core CPI. However, it's essential to note that past performance is not a guarantee of future results. Given these factors, it's challenging to make a definitive prediction about the direction of the Core CPI in July. However, considering the moderate economic expansion and the potential for upward pressure on wages and prices, I would slightly favor the possibility of a small increase in the Core CPI.

question.body:

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

(a) On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Biden does not drop out and is able to continue the race until July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. If Biden drops out before this time, the question will resolve as "No".

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, I will consider several factors. Firstly, the Scottish National Party (SNP) has been advocating for Scottish independence and has a majority in the Scottish Parliament. This suggests a strong political will for a referendum. However, the UK government has historically been reluctant to grant permission for a referendum, and there have been instances of 'wildcat' or 'Catalan' style referendums being held without official sanction. Nevertheless, the SNP has been working to build a consensus for a referendum, and there have been efforts to engage with the UK government on this issue. Additionally, the resolution date is approaching, which may create a sense of urgency and increase the likelihood of a referendum being held. However, it's also possible that the UK government may continue to resist granting permission for a referendum, or that the SNP may not be able to build sufficient support for a referendum. Given these factors, I would estimate the probability of a sanctioned referendum being held before May 3, 2024, as follows.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President, or (b) Russia has control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:
- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine
- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours
- Assessed Russian Control
- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine
- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location
The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:
- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours
- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives
- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare
- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of either of the two scenarios occurring, I'll consider the likelihood of each individual scenario. For scenario (a), I'll evaluate the probability of Joe Biden announcing that he won't accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024. Given that this is a specific and high-stakes announcement, I expect it to be well-covered by the media, and it's likely that we'll know about any such announcement as soon as it happens. However, it's difficult to estimate the probability of such an announcement without more information on Biden's current intentions. I'll assume that it's unlikely for Biden to make such an announcement unless he's very certain that he won't accept the nomination. I'll conservatively estimate the probability of this scenario at 20%. For scenario (b), I'll consider the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024. I'll rely on the provided information from the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map, which indicates that the area is currently assessed as a Ukrainian-held territory. Without more information on the likelihood of a change in the control of this area by June 1, 2024, I'll assume that it's still a Ukrainian-held territory and estimate the probability of this scenario at 10%. Given that these two scenarios are independent of each other, I'll calculate the probability of either scenario occurring by adding the probabilities of each individual scenario. The probability of either scenario (a) or (b) occurring is 0.2 + 0.1 = 0.3.

This is because the two events are independent of each other, meaning that the outcome of one event does not affect the outcome of the other event. Therefore, the probability of both Estonia qualifying and Georgia failing to qualify is: 0.25 (probability of Estonia qualifying) x 0.45 (probability of Georgia failing to qualify) = 0.1125. question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Georgia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, or (b) Estonia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of either Georgia or Estonia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider the process of Eurovision's semi-finals and finals. The Grand Final qualification is determined by the results of the Semi-finals, where the top 10 countries from each semi-final qualify for the Grand Final. Georgia and Estonia are both European countries participating in the contest, and they will likely participate in one of the two Semi-finals. Assuming that the Semi-final draw is random and fair, and that the qualification process is also fair, we can estimate the probability of either Georgia or Estonia qualifying for the Grand Final. There are 25 other countries in the same Semi-final as Georgia (or Estonia), and 25 countries in the other Semi-final. The probability of Georgia (or Estonia) qualifying from their Semi-final is 10/26. Since Georgia and Estonia can be in either Semi-final, we need to consider both scenarios. The probability of at least one of them qualifying is 1 - (probability of neither qualifying). The probability of neither Georgia nor Estonia qualifying is (16/26)^2, therefore the probability of at least one of them qualifying is 1 - (16/26)^2, which gives us a probability of approximately 0.657.

question.title: If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance?
question.body:

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(2) Either the United States men's or women's basketball team places anywhere other than gold at the Paris Olympics.

The probability of the 76ers winning the NBA Finals is difficult to estimate without more information about their season performance and potential playoff path. However, considering the strength of the US basketball team and the quality of their competition, it's unlikely that they would fail to win gold in both tournaments. Assuming an equal chance for the US to win gold in each tournament, the probability of them winning gold in both is (1/2) x (1/2) = 1/4. Therefore, the probability of the US failing to win gold in either tournament is 1 - 1/4 = 3/4. Combining these two probabilities using the multiplication rule for independent events, we get: P(76ers win and US fails to win gold) = P(76ers win) x P(US fails to win gold) = 1/30 x 3/4 = 1/40. So, the probability of the question resolving Yes is 1/40.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, I'll consider several factors that could influence the likelihood of a multi-round voting process. Firstly, the number of candidates in the Democratic primary is a crucial factor. A crowded field with multiple strong contenders increases the chances of a brokered convention. However, if the field is relatively small, with one or two clear front-runners, the likelihood of a brokered convention decreases. Secondly, the current polling and delegate lead of the top contenders will play a significant role. If one candidate has a substantial lead in both national polls and delegate count, it's less likely that the convention will be brokered. On the other hand, if the lead is narrow or non-existent, it increases the chances of a brokered convention. Thirdly, the rules of the Democratic Party's primary process, such as the use of proportional allocation of delegates or the threshold for delegates to be awarded, can also impact the likelihood of a brokered convention. If the rules favor a more proportional allocation of delegates, it's more likely that multiple candidates will have a significant number of delegates, increasing the chances of a brokered convention. Lastly, the dynamics of the primary campaign, including the level of polarization, the effectiveness of the candidates' campaigns, and any potential scandals or controversies, can also influence the likelihood of a brokered convention. Given these factors, I'll need more information about the current state of the Democratic primary, including the number of candidates, their polling and delegate leads, and the rules of the primary process. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

Since there are 8 teams competing in each sport, the probability of all teams winning at most one gold medal is (0.999987)^8 ≈ 0.999998. Now, let's consider condition (b). This is equivalent to the probability that each athlete wins at most one gold medal. We can calculate this using the binomial distribution. Since there are approximately 64 athletes competing in tennis, the probability of all athletes winning at most one gold medal is (0.917)^64 ≈ 0.38. Now that we have estimated the probabilities of each condition, we can find the joint probability of both conditions being met. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

The context from Politico suggests that there is a group of House Democrats organizing a plan to speak out against the early nomination, and a drafted letter has been circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman. This indicates that there is some level of opposition to the plan within the Democratic Party. However, it's unclear whether this opposition will translate into a public letter signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators. The fact that the market resolves YES if a public letter is signed by at least 20 lawmakers who caucus with the Democratic Party suggests that the market is looking for a specific level of public opposition to the plan. Given the context, it seems plausible that a public letter could be signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators, but it's also possible that the opposition may not be able to mobilize enough signatures to meet the threshold.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

Section 4 specifics: The question specifically asks about Section 4 of the 25th Amendment, which requires a formal declaration by the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) that the President is unable to discharge their duties. Recent context: A GOP lawmaker has asked Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, but this is not a formal request and lacks the necessary support from a majority of the Cabinet. The request is likely a political maneuver rather than a serious attempt to invoke the amendment. 5. Timeframe: The question asks about the timeframe before August 2024, which is a relatively short period. Given the complexities and challenges involved in invoking the 25th Amendment, it is unlikely that the necessary steps would be taken within such a short timeframe. Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is low.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a brokered convention occurring, we need to consider the factors that influence the likelihood of multiple rounds of voting in the Democratic Party's nomination process. A brokered convention typically happens when no candidate has secured a majority of the delegates before the convention, leading to a contested convention where delegates are free to switch their votes. Several factors indicate a low likelihood of a brokered convention in 2024: 1. Early voting and primary schedule: The Democratic primary schedule has moved earlier in the election cycle, which means that many states will have held their primaries or caucuses before the convention. This typically leads to a clearer picture of the front-runner, making it less likely for the nomination to be contested. 2. Front-runner's strength: The strength of the front-runner, such as a candidate who has a broad coalition of support and significant fundraising capabilities, can make it less likely for other candidates to catch up and force a brokered convention. 3. Delegate math: The Democratic Party's delegate allocation system, which is based on a proportional representation of votes in each state, can lead to a situation where no candidate has a majority of delegates, but this is not a guarantee of a brokered convention. 4. Recent trends: In recent years, the Democratic Party has moved to more proportional allocation of delegates, which can make it less likely for a clear winner to emerge early in the process. Considering these factors, while not impossible, a brokered convention seems unlikely. However, the political landscape can change rapidly due to various factors such as candidate performances, scandals, and shifts in public opinion.

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, I will consider the following factors: 1. Typically, polling averages tend to fluctuate within a certain range, and it's rare for a candidate to lead by a margin of exactly 2 or 3 points. 2. 538's polling model: FiveThirtyEight's polling model is widely regarded as one of the most accurate and reliable in the industry. Their model takes into account a large number of polls, weights them according to their quality and sample size, and produces a weighted average of the results. This model is likely to produce a more accurate estimate of the true margin between Trump and Biden. 3. Historical context: In previous elections, polling averages have often shown a range of margins between the leading candidate and their closest opponent. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Firstly, the fact that dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their party's effort indicates a significant level of opposition. The drafted letter circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman and obtained by Politico further suggests that there is a clear intention to express dissent. Additionally, the context from Politico implies that the opposition to the early nomination plan is not limited to just a small group of individuals, but rather a broader segment of the Democratic Party. The fact that scores of members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy suggests that there is a significant amount of discontent within the party. While it's impossible to predict with certainty the outcome, the available information suggests that the conditions for the market to resolve YES are likely to be met. The fact that multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmakers' signatures would also be sufficient to resolve the market to YES provides an additional layer of flexibility, making it more likely that the market will resolve YES.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Both countries have participated in Eurovision in recent years, making it likely they will do so again in 2024. However, the qualification for the Grand Final is not guaranteed due to the competitive nature of the event and the EBU's selection process. Without real-time information, I estimate a moderate probability for each country, leading to a combined probability of around 0.6 for either Switzerland or Portugal qualifying.
